subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: An alternative to the usual ghost hunter stuff.
author: Rj
full_text:
--0-1531180119-1239836267=:42336
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Asking the board open-ended questions, and interpreting the results, is sub=
jective. Asking for a specific, predetermined number is not subjective.=C2=
=A0 It is about as objective as you can get. 

I am not trying to prove any=
thing, or rule out any possibilities.=C2=A0 I am suggesting a method to det=
ermine, statistically, how accurate someone=E2=80=99s board, or methodology=
, might be.=C2=A0 Lets say I select two people, and in separate rooms, I gi=
ve each a spelling test.=C2=A0 Person 1 gets 100% right.=C2=A0 Person 2 get=
s 50% right.=C2=A0 Now, if I later give them a second spelling test, I can =
start with the theory that Person 1 will get near 100% correct, and Person =
2 will get near 50% correct.=C2=A0 This doesn=E2=80=99t mean they will, or =
that they have gotten these scores in the past.=C2=A0 But statistically, it=
 is a reasonable assumption at this point.=C2=A0 After the second test, I c=
an examine the deviation of the results from the first test, and update the=
 statistics.=C2=A0=C2=A0 If the deviation remains small (if the results rem=
ain similar), then I can more and more safely assume that person 1 will hav=
e a very high chance of getting a word right, and person 2 will have half t=
hat.=C2=A0 If the
 deviation swings wildly, than my statistics may not be v=
ery predictive after all.

The same is true with the board.=C2=A0 As you sa=
id, getting this number wrong doesn=E2=80=99t say past answers were wrong, =
or that future answers will be wrong.=C2=A0 And it is possible it could hav=
e been right by mere chance (though very unlikely: winning the lottery is m=
ore likely than guessing one number out of a billion).=C2=A0 What we=E2=80=
=99d have is one single objective data point.=C2=A0 It gives a starting poi=
nt for reasonable assumptions.=C2=A0 As you noted, after more such tests, t=
hose assumptions may start changing.=C2=A0 It would be interesting to see h=
ow they change, if they do.

Different people seem to have different feelin=
gs about the board.=C2=A0 Some believe it gives great results.=C2=A0 Some a=
re suspicious, even dubious.=C2=A0 And there are plenty of opinions in betw=
een.=C2=A0 My test is not for those who believe it is statistically likely =
that psychic tampering would occur, or that the board=E2=80=99s performance=
 is just not testable, which is the camp I gather you are in.=C2=A0 My test=
 is only good for that segment of this population who believes or wonders i=
f the board is capable of giving a straight objective answer to a straight =
objective questions, and that such performance is testable.=C2=A0 To addres=
s one of your examples, while it cannot show that an entity is reading my m=
ind if it gets the numbers right, it can conversely show that an actual ent=
ity is not reading my mind (or that it is not performing remote viewing, or=
 that it is not predicting the future of what the right answer is when it i=
s revealed, or that it is not being forthright in
 its answers) if it canno=
t get the numbers right in the first place.=C2=A0 But if these things are t=
rue, then it begs the question of its accuracy anyway.

So again, this is o=
ne data point, in what could be a number of tests, for those who are not ru=
ling out that testing is possible, and even desirable, when believing, or a=
cting on, information gathered by using this kind of board.=C2=A0

It's not that I don't want to te=
st 
it,=C2=A0it is that I can't. It would be interesting and I would do it =
if I 
could.
=C2=A0
But again, this test could really only rule 
out psychi=
c interference from you. It is too subjective and therefore cannot 
stand a=
s a measurement for other tests of=C2=A0this nature by 
itself.
=C2=A0
If i=
t failed to get your number,=C2=A0that 
would not mean that it couldn't get=
 someone else's number or that someone else 
couldn't influence it. That wo=
uld also not mean that=C2=A0answers it had gotten 
in the past weren't corr=
ect,=C2=A0coming from a living being or a spirit.=C2=A0 
It would not prove=
 anything, except that it was not acting on any psychic 
vibrations from yo=
u personally.
=C2=A0
If it got your number correct, that doesn't 
even help=
 immediately, because it could get the answer on mere 
chance.
=C2=A0
The o=
nly way to prove here that it is being 
psychically influenced would be to =
run several tests of the same nature. Then, 
if it scored correct higher th=
en mere chance, only then could you say that the 
board can be psychically =
tampered with.=C2=A0Still, that is the only thing you 
could say for certai=
n. That would not=C2=A0rule=C2=A0out the possibility that 
spirits can comm=
unicate through it.
=C2=A0
=C2=A0So we would be left with=C2=A0more 
questi=
ons. Is it that it is being psychically tampered with by a human mind 
dire=
ctly? Is it and actual entity reading someone's mind? Can it be 
both?
=C2=
=A0
See what I am sayin'?
=C2=A0
=C2=A0

      If you don't want to test =
it, I understand.=C2=A0 This is 
        only a suggestion for people who w=
ant to test it.=C2=A0 An objective 
        test, such as this, would be I =
think a good way to determine its 
        accuracy.=C2=A0 And its accuracy=
 is what carries over into its overall 
        performance and value.=C2=
=A0 If you have no measurement as to the 
        accuracy of its results, =
or of a given methodology, then that brings 
        into questions its ove=
rall results, and so, its other 
        answers.

Again, though, if you do=
n't want to test it, I 
        understand.

 number is not subjective.  It is about as objective as you can get. <=

sp; I am suggesting a method to determine, statistically, how accurate some=
one=E2=80=99s board, or methodology, might be.  Lets say I select two =
people, and in separate rooms, I give each a spelling test.  Person 1 =
gets 100% right.  Person 2 gets 50% right.  Now, if I later give =
them a second spelling test, I can start with the theory that Person 1 will=
 get near 100% correct, and Person 2 will get near 50% correct.  This =
doesn=E2=80=99t mean they will, or that they have gotten these scores in th=
e past.  But statistically, it is a reasonable assumption at this poin=
t.  After
 the second test, I can examine the deviation of the results=
 from the first test, and update the statistics.   If the deviati=
on remains small (if the results remain similar), then I can more and more =
safely assume that person 1 will have a very high chance of getting a word =
right, and person 2 will have half that.  If the deviation swings wild=
ly, than my statistics may not be very predictive after all.<br><br>The sam=
e is true with the board.  As you said, getting this number wrong does=

ng.  And it is possible it could have been right by mere chance (thoug=
h very unlikely: winning the lottery is more likely than guessing one numbe=
r out of a billion).  What we=E2=80=99d have is one single objective d=
ata point.  It gives a starting point for reasonable assumptions.&nbsp=
; As you noted, after more such tests, those assumptions may start changing=
.  It would be
 interesting to see how they change, if they do.<br><br=

  And there are plenty of opinions in between.  My test is not fo=
r those who believe it is statistically likely that psychic tampering would=

t such performance is testable.  To address one of your examples, whil=
e it cannot show that an entity is reading my mind if it gets the numbers r=
ight, it can conversely show that an actual entity is not reading my mind (=
or that it is not performing remote viewing, or that it is not predicting t=
he future of what
 the right answer is when it is revealed, or that it is n=
ot being forthright in its answers) if it cannot get the numbers right in t=
he first place.  But if these things are true, then it begs the questi=
on of its accuracy anyway.<br><br>So again, this is one data point, in what=
